author: FOX 9 Staff
title: Grandma‚Äôs Marathon sells out in near-record time
text:
article DULUTH, Minn. (FOX 9) - Grandma's Marathon in Duluth has sold out for the fourth year in a row ‚Äî and in near-record time.
The popular race, which is held annually in June, reached its second-fastest sellout in the race's history, reaching its capacity of 9,500 participants signing up for this year's 26.2-mile road race from Two Harbors to Duluth.
"It‚Äôs a humbling thing, to see thousands of people so excited to be part of Grandma‚Äôs Marathon," Marketing & Public Relations Director Zach Schneider said in a statement. "It‚Äôs reason for celebration, and now the real work begins to ensure these participants, all of whom have signed up early and are looking forward to the race, have the experience they paid for and are expecting in June."
According to organizers, the 2016 race ‚Äî the largest in the race's history with 7,518 finishers ‚Äî set the record for selling out, reaching its capacity on Dec. 31, 2015. It's the event's only sellout that's earlier than the 2024 race.
While the main field for Grandma's Marathon has reached capacity, there are a few ways people can still participate in the 2024 event. Among them: be part of the official training group; be a charity runner and join the bib transfer portal.
Grandma's Marathon is the 10th largest marathon in the United States.

author: Rick Rickman
title: Driver stabbed in Paramus, NJ road rage incident, officials say
text: Driver stabbed in sudden Paramus, NJ road rage incident, officials say üî¥ A man was taken to the hospital after being stabbed on Route 4 üî¥ The suspect drove a white BMW, a report said üî¥ An investigation is ongoing PARAMUS ‚Äî Authorities are trying to locate the driver of a BMW after they got out of their car and stabbed another person on Route 4 late Thursday morning, according to a report. The BMW and a van were both headed eastbound on Route 4 and got into an argument east of Forest Avenue around 11:30 a.m., the [Daily Voice](https://dailyvoice.com/new-jersey/paramus/route-4-stabbing-manhunt-on-for-road-rage-driver-who-fled/) reported. The driver of the BMW got out of the car and stabbed the other man in the back and arm, Paramus police Chief Robert Guidetti reportedly said. Paramus police responding to a 911 call found the 28-year-old male victim soon after, according to the Bergen County Prosecutor's Office. Photos from the scene showed officers from the Bergen County Sheriff's Office and Paramus police on the road near Popeyes. Police notified the public on [social media](https://www.facebook.com/paramuspolice/posts/pfbid0tu7KLhHdg5d7FE1Z5csghtscRTdpormysc4F9RAa8LE8JBLhxxjaVAg3Rx1mhf5ol) around 11:40 a.m. of heavy delays in the area for the investigation. The victim was treated at Hackensack University Medical Center and was in stable condition as of 3:50 p.m. An investigation is ongoing. No arrests have been announced. The stabbing comes one day after the Hunterdon County Prosecutor's Office announced the arrest of a Queens man in connection to [another road rage incident](https://nj1015.com/nj-police-arrest-queens-man-for-i-78-road-rage-shooting/) this month in North Jersey. Authorities said Collen Brown, 25, fired a handgun at a tractor-trailer headed east on Interstate 78 on Dec. 13. He is being held at Warren County jail. [Report a correction](mailto:trenton.dme@townsquaremedia.com?subject=Feedback or correction) üëà | üëâ [Contact our newsroom](https://nj1015.com/contact-nj-1015-newsroom/) Celebrities Who Were Murdered Gallery Credit: [Natasha Reda](https://popcrush.com/murdered-celebrities/) LOOK: Best counties to raise a family in New Jersey [Stacker](https://stacker.com/new-jersey/best-counties-raise-family-new-jersey)compiled a list of the best counties to raise a family in New Jersey. author: Fran G. Sas
title: FIESTA DE SAN AMARO EN ALD√ÅN: La lluvia no impide la primera verbena del a√±o en la comarca
text: Ald√°n vivi√≥ ayer una jornada de fiesta. Todav√≠a con las navidades a la vuelta de la esquina y con los carnavales a un mes escaso, los vecinos de esta parroquia canguesa celebraron la primera verbena del a√±o en la comarca. Se trata de San Amaro. La celebraci√≥n de este a√±o estuvo marcada por la lluvia, que impidi√≥ que saliese la procesi√≥n con las im√°genes de San Amaro y de Santa Mari√±a alrededor del atrio de la capilla. Sin embargo, s√≠ que se celebr√≥ la misa solemne, que comenz√≥ a las 13.00 horas, despu√©s de otras tres ceremonias religiosas. Durante toda la jornada se tiraron fuegos en Ald√°n y durante la misa decenas de vecinos llenaron la carpa instalada por la comisi√≥n para disfrutar de productos gastron√≥micos como pulpo, empanada o callos, mientras actuaba la Charanga Noroeste. Tambi√©n se celebr√≥ la tradicional Queima de Monecos, muy caracter√≠stica de esta fiesta, aunque la humedad de la ma√±ana de ayer impidi√≥ que estallasen. Aunque la fiesta fue entre semana, la verbena nocturna se celebr√≥ desde las 19.30 horas con las orquestas Saudade de Vigo y Arena Musical. Antes, por el atrio se pasaron las familias para disfrutar de juegos populares y de la actuaci√≥n de Codia e Miolo.

author: Andrew Benson Global News
title: Saskatchewan partners with Alberta and Ontario in struggle with mental illness and addiction | Globalnews.ca
text:
Three provinces are coming together to fight the battle against mental illness and addictions.
The main goal of the partnership of Saskatchewan, Alberta, and Ontario is to create recovery care plans. It will be an information-sharing partnership as they move to a recovery-oriented system of care.
‚ÄúSaskatchewan is focused on helping people overcome addictions and live healthy, safe lives,‚Äù Tim McLeod, Minister of Mental Health and Addictions, Seniors and Rural and Remote Health, Saskatchewan said.
‚ÄúBy helping people overcome addictions, we can save lives, heal families and strengthen our communities.‚Äù
Over the last two days, ministers from Alberta, Sask., and Ontario met in Calgary for the eighth annual Recovery Capital Conference of Canada.
Alberta‚Äôs recovery model will act as the base for the new partnership, meant to break down barriers and increase access to recovery services.
Story continues below advertisement ‚ÄúWe are eager to share the Alberta Recovery Model because we believe it is the most dignified, comprehensive and compassionate approach in any jurisdiction across Canada to help people overcome their mental health challenges and recover from the deadly disease of addiction,‚Äù Alberta Minister of Mental Health and Addiction, Dan Williams, said.
1:50 Addiction conference debates recovery focused care in Calgary Earlier this week, Alberta unveiled two new agencies to deliver mental health and addiction services.
The latest health and medical news emailed to you every Sunday. Recovery Alberta will be tasked with delivering mental health and addiction services currently covered by Alberta Health Services. The province is also establishing a new Crown corporation called the Canadian Centre of Recovery Excellence.
Saskatchewan has not made the same announcement but will be working with Alberta and Ontario to develop new plans to treat mental health and addiction.
Trending Now O.J. Simpson dies of cancer at 76 Ottawa changing RRSP Home Buyers‚Äô Plan, some mortgage amortization rules ‚ÄúThe path to recovery is a lifelong journey for individuals and so when individuals are walking that path, they may cross borders to the neighbouring provinces and if we have a unified approach where we‚Äôre all focused on recovery orientated systems of care and recovery model, I think that is better serving the people using the systems,‚Äù McLeod said.
Story continues below advertisement The partnership comes after Saskatchewan shifted its approach to handling addictions, by eliminating funding for harm reduction services to provide drug tools.
According to the Saskatchewan coroner‚Äôs office‚Äôs latest report on drug toxicity deaths, since the start of 2024 there have been 26 deaths and 87 suspected deaths due to drug toxicity.
The government faced heavy backlash when it decided to no longer provide drug tools to harm reduction services.
McLeod said this new approach to battle addictions through wrap-around recovery services will focus on treating the person and not the addiction.
‚ÄúWe need to identify what that specific individual needs and I would say that what they need is not more drugs,‚Äù he said. ‚ÄúWhat they need are supports that will address the underlying trauma and they need the supports that will get them on a path to recovery.‚Äù
McLeod also said the provinces naloxone and overdose outreach programs will help bring people to wrap-around services, and that the collaboration of ideas and initiatives with Alberta and Ontario will be more beneficial in treating people across all provinces.
More on Health ‚ÄòCareful evaluation needed‚Äô: Seemingly contradictory studies of B.C.‚Äôs safer supply released Is there a link between stroke and climate change? A study may have found one Canadian researchers create natural supplement to combat postpartum blues RCMP‚Äôs ‚ÄòName the Foal‚Äô contest to name new police horses now open for entries

author: I. Gonz√°lez
title: Se mantiene la huelga general en la log√≠stica de Solvay tras una nueva mediaci√≥n sin acuerdo
text: La huelga general indefinida convocada en el servicio de log√≠stica de Solvay se mantiene desde el pr√≥ximo martes 3 de diciembre, tras concluir este viernes sin acuerdo una nueva mediaci√≥n entre los sindicatos y la empresa concesionaria Katoen Natie convocada por el Organismo de Resoluci√≥n Extrajudicial de Conflictos Laborales (ORECLA). El comit√© de empresa de la log√≠stica de la f√°brica de Barreda (UGT, CCOO y USO) prosigue as√≠ con sus movilizaciones, incluidos los paros de dos horas en cada turno de trabajo iniciados este pasado lunes 25 de noviembre y secundados hasta el momento por una media de un 90% de la plantilla de f√°brica, seg√∫n los sindicatos. El presidente del comit√© de empresa de Katoen Natie, Lorenzo Fern√°ndez (UGT), ha explicado en un comunicado que tras la reuni√≥n en el ORECLA, "todo sigue igual porque la empresa no quiere saber nada de respetar nuestros derechos laborales ya adquiridos de anteriores concesionarias, ni de pagarnos los t√≥xicos y penosos que cobra toda la f√°brica menos nosotros ni de proteger la salud y seguridad de la plantilla con un cumplimiento estricto de las normas de prevenci√≥n de riesgos laborales". Por eso, la plantilla pasar√° de los paros de dos horas a la huelga general indefinida a partir del pr√≥ximo martes, que continuar√° "hasta cuando sea necesario", ha advertido Fern√°ndez. Adem√°s, ha anunciado que el comit√© de empresa ya ha denunciado a la Inspecci√≥n de Trabajo, y lo demandar√° en los tribunales de justicia, que la empresa est√© sustituyendo a trabajadores en paro por empleados de empresas de trabajo temporal. "Es inaceptable e ilegal que se vulnere de un modo tan descarado el derecho constitucional a la huelga y no lo vamos a permitir", ha aseverado el presidente del comit√©, que ha criticado que, tras casi un mes de movilizaciones, "ni la empresa ni Solvay, que es quien paga, se dan por aludidas". La huelga general en el servicio de log√≠stica de Solvay del 3 de diciembre, que afecta a una plantilla de 73 trabajadores, sucede a las concentraciones de protesta que se iniciaron en la porter√≠a de la f√°brica de Barreda el 4 de noviembre y los posteriores paros horarios que comenzaron el pasado lunes 25.

author: Jake Romphf
title: B.C. coastal island land being donated for protection - Kelowna Capital News
text: After its abundant biodiversity has been stewarded by First Nations for thousands of years and it‚Äôs been eyed for pristine parkland for a century, parts of an island off B.C.‚Äôs Central Coast are closer to being protected forever. At a March 13 ceremony in Victoria, Tula Foundation founders Eric Peterson and Christina Munck announced they would be transferring two parcels, totalling 55 acres, of Calvert Island to the BC Parks Foundation. The land will be incorporated into the island‚Äôs Hakai Luxvbalis Conservancy, which is collaboratively managed by the province and the Heiltsuk and Wuikinuxv First Nations. The founders also announced a donation of $92 million to Tula in support of the organization advancing its scientific innovation. READ MORE: [B.C. couple gives away last $92M, wants others to pick up the baton](https://www.vicnews.com/news/bc-couple-gives-away-last-92m-wants-others-to-pick-up-the-baton-7329547) Peterson called Calvert Island the most iconic place on B.C.‚Äôs coast as it features breathtaking beaches and incredible biodiversity. It‚Äôs also a sacred place for First Nations, he said, noting inhabitants have gathered on the land for over 10,000 years. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs not just any piece of real estate, it‚Äôs an extraordinary place,‚Äù the Tula founder said, highlighting the island‚Äôs complex coastlines carved by glaciation and how it sits among a labyrinth of land and sea along the Central Coast. Those comments were echoed by Andy Day, the BC Parks Foundation‚Äôs CEO, as he touted the incredible stretch of beach and ecology that make up the donated plots. With the site also hosting rich old-growth forests, Day said the Calvert lands are emblematic of the province‚Äôs ecological bounty. Species are under threat around the world, Day said, adding 70 per cent of the world‚Äôs biodiversity has been lost in the last 50 years. Protecting land in perpetuity though actions like the Calvert donation is among the only ways to address that crisis, he said. ‚ÄúAlong with First Nations people and the province of British Columbia, we will make sure that it continues to be managed responsibly for all British Columbians to enjoy and for all the species in that area to enjoy,‚Äù Day said. The CEO hopes the move inspires people to connect with B.C.‚Äôs natural areas and spurs other land donations. The gifted plots have had a complex and fought history, Peterson explained. Archaeological findings show signs of human settlement on the island from 13,000 years ago and around 5,000 years back, it hosted industrial-scale shellfish agriculture with clam gardens, processing areas, drying racks and trading sites. First Nations oral histories recount a settlement known as Luxvbalis that was visited by Captain Vancouver. Luxvbalis was devastated by smallpox epidemic of 1862 and many of the dead were abandoned in one of the island‚Äôs bays. ‚ÄúThere‚Äôs many souls from many Nations that have never been properly mourned in this place,‚Äù Peterson said. The donated lands were surveyed after the First World War and a group envisioned it as protected parkland around 1925. The sites welcomed gathering and recreation for the next 40 years as they were effectively used as a park, but were then bought after the protections were never made official, Peterson said. The sites were then logged for their cedar giants before they were taken over in the ‚Äô90s to host a beach resort. That resort created friction with First Nations, other neighbours and BC Parks as the area was closed off from the public. Those tensions escalated in the 2000s under a new U.S. owner who gated the land. Since Tula bought the plots in 2009 and reopened them to the public, Peterson said he‚Äôs thrilled by their current partnership with neighbouring First Nations and he hopes to start conversations with them and all levels of government on transferring a third Calvert property. ‚ÄúThey can be assured now that the future of these two parcels is secured for everyone to enjoy,‚Äù Peterson said. The Tula Foundation‚Äôs Hakai Institute hosts an ecological observatory on Calvert Island that has opened research opportunities to those like Brian Starzomski. He‚Äôs one of the many University of Victoria researchers to study at the facility, and said the chance to work there has been lifechanging for scores of students. ‚ÄúThe most amazing things would happen at this place,‚Äù he said, recounting scientists from diverse disciplines debating the origins of Calvert‚Äôs geography while they dined together at the island. ‚ÄúSo many great research programs and papers came out of these discussions, it‚Äôs one of Eric and Christina‚Äôs great skills, they bring people together and support them with everything they need to do amazing things.‚Äù READ: [Citizen scientist‚Äôs fight for bird habitat access denied](https://www.vicnews.com/local-news/citizen-scientists-fight-for-bird-habitat-access-denied-7329150)

author: @tgc_au
title: Easter: A Welcome Holiday, a Wild Story - The Gospel Coalition | Australia
text: Easter is approaching, and while we don‚Äôt all believe, or even know the ‚ÄúEaster Story‚Äù, I think we‚Äôre all on board with the holiday part. But as far as stories go, it is one worth hearing‚Äîfull of action, tragedy, mystery, and unexpected twists. The Easter Story It‚Äôs about how a small-town Jewish guy who makes the most outrageous claim‚Äîthat he is God‚Äîsomehow grows so popular, and arouses so much jealousy among the religious leaders of his day, they have him killed. But that‚Äôs not all! Three days later his body disappears and he starts popping up all over the place‚Äî [he‚Äôs mistaken for a gardene](https://bible.com.au/NIV/JHN/20/11-15)r, [he‚Äôs seen eating fish](https://bible.com.au/NIV/LUK/24/40-43), [he shows a skeptical friend the marks in his hands](https://bible.com.au/NIV/JHN/20/24-29)‚Ä¶ Turns out the whole crucifixion thing was God‚Äôs plan all along. Not long after all this, there‚Äôs a scene where the dead (?) guy‚Äôs mates are rounded up and brought before an assembly of religious leaders. They‚Äôve already been jailed once, but there was an issue with the locks‚Äîor divine intervention?‚Äî either way, they escaped. When the apostles are unapologetic about the trouble they‚Äôre causing‚Äîthey ‚Äúobey God, not man‚Äù‚Äîthe appalled leaders want to not just jail them (again) but put them to death. But one of the leaders‚Äô number disagrees; [ this guy urges peers to let the apostles go instead](https://bible.com.au/NIV/ACT/5/34-40). He reckons that if their claims are a crock, they‚Äôll be forgotten soon enough. But if they‚Äôre somehow from God‚Äîare somehow true‚Äîthere‚Äôll be no stopping them; the religious leaders will only find themselves ‚Äúfighting against God‚Äù (not a good look for religious leaders). The Easter Story Today A couple of thousand years later, the claims the apostles made about Jesus‚Äîthat he really did die and really did come back to life, that he really was divine‚Äîare still being made. Christianity might be declining in some places, but it‚Äôs thriving in others. That outrageous guy, whose body never was found, is worshiped still‚Äînot just by a handful of kooks, but by people all over the world. It‚Äôs bizarre to claim that death is not the end and yet, isn‚Äôt it bizarre to claim it is? Author and journalist Helen Garner, when writing about a visit to Melbourne‚Äôs Springvale crematorium, wrote about this realisation: I didn‚Äôt start shaking and crying till two days later. And on my way home, I had, for the first time in my life, a conviction‚ÄîI mean not a thought but knowledge‚Äîthat life can‚Äôt possibly end at death. I had the punctuation wrong. I thought it was a full stop, but it‚Äôs only a comma, or a dash‚Äîor better still, a colon: I don‚Äôt believe in heaven or hell, or punishment or reward, or the survival of the ego; but what about energy, spirit, soul, imagination, love? The force for which we have no word? How preposterous, to think that it could die! [ [1]](#_ftn1) [There‚Äôs this this prophecy in the book of Isaiah](https://bible.com.au/NIV/ISA/53/3/), written long before Jesus was born, about how the coming Messiah would be despised and rejected. It‚Äôs preparing the Jews for a king who won‚Äôt come in glory, but humility; who will be crowned not with gold but thorns; who will die a slave‚Äôs death. You could argue this prophecy reached its fulfillment when Jesus was crucified. But you could also argue it‚Äôs fulfilled every day. You could even argue it‚Äôs ironically fulfilled every time someone mutters or shouts ‚ÄúJESUS CHRIST!‚Äù Whether you curse his name or revere it, there‚Äôs something to be said for those ancient predictions. And there‚Äôs something to be said for the theory that if the claims about Jesus weren‚Äôt from God, they‚Äôd have been lost to history long ago. Instead, whether in praise or in cursing, his name is spoken every day. [[1]](#_ftnref1) ‚ÄòDeath‚Äô in True Stories: The Collected Short Non-Fiction.
